questions.text:
Which of the following is the cause of cicatricial alopecia?
1. Alopecia areata
2. Telogen effluvium
3. Androgenic alopecia
4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Scarring alopecia:

  • DLE
  • Lichen Planopilaris
  • SLE (Both scarring and nonscarring)
  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia _____(4)
  • Pseudopelade of brocq
  • Kerion
  • Favus
  • Folliculitis

Nonscarring alopecia:

  • Grey patch tinea capitis
  • Black dot tinea capitis
  • Androgenic alopecia____(3)
  • Alopecia areata_______(1)
  • Telogen effluvium______(2)
  • Trichotillomania
  • Nutritional deficiency

Frontal fibrosing alopecia is characterized by a band of cicatricial alopecia from the anterior hairline. Sometimes associated with madarosis (loss of eyebrow)

Key takeaway:

questions.text: A 37 year old female known case of hypothyroidism presented with patchy hair loss over scalp since 1 month. Identify the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
• The image given here is smooth bald patch over scalp suggests diagnosis of alopecia areata.
  • On dermoscopy, there is classical exclamation hair.
  • In histopathology, lymphocytic infiltration around hair follicle (Swarm of bees appearance) is seen
  • There are three main types of alopecia areata:

Option A: Sebaceous cyst:

A sebaceous cyst is a benign growth of the skin that occurs due to blocked sebaceous glands. It typically appears as a firm lump under the skin and punctum on the skin surface.

Option C: Trichotillomania

  • Trichotillomania (TTM) also known as hair-pulling disorder,
  • Trichotillomania is part of OCD and is thought to be largely related to anxiety disorders.
  • Classical tonsular appearance (Friar tuck appearance)
  • Trichoscopy of trichotillomania is characterized by presence of hairs broken at different length, black dots, trichoptilosis, coiled hairs, flame hairs, V-sign and tulip hairs.

Option D: Tinea capitis

It is dermatophyte infection of hair. It occurs predominantly in prepubertal children.

The clinical features may be broadly categorised into non-inflammatory and inflammatory variants.

Key takeaway:

Alopecia areata.

  • Autoimmune condition
  • Associated with other autoimmune diseases, including thyroid disorders.
  • Smooth bald patch
  • On dermoscopy, there is classical exclamation hair.
  • In histopathology, lymphocytic infiltration around hair follicle (Swarm of bees appearance)

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of this condition affecting hair?
questions.solution:
This picture shows polarizing microscopy of hair with "tiger tail band" appearance, seen in trichothiodystrophy.

Trichothiodystrophy

  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder.
  • Abnormal synthesis of sulphur containing aminoacid leads to deficiency of cysteine and methionine. Thus, hairs are rough and fragile resulting in Tiger tail appearance.
  • Clinically patient presents with diffuse sparseness and broken hair all over scalp since childhood.
  • It can be associated with_
    PIBIDS
    P- Photosensitivity
    I- Ichthyosis
    B- Brittle hair
    I- Intellectual impairment
    D- Decreased fertility
    S- Short stature

Option A: Trichorrhexis nodosa

It is a hair shaft defect with nodes in hair shaft

Option B: Trichorrhexis invaginata

  • It is hair shaft disorder.
  • Hair shaft telescopes into itself along the shaft (Invaganation) "Ball and Socket" appearance
  • Trichorrhexis invaginata is pathognomonic of Netherton syndrome
  • Netherton syndrom consists triad of
    1. Atopic dermatitis
    2. Trichorrhexis invaginata
    3. Ichthyosis linearis circumflexa (Double edged scales)

Option D: Monilethrix

It is a hair shaft defect with beaded appearance in hair shaft

Key takeaway:

Trichothiodystrophy

  • Autosomal recessive disorder.
  • Abnormal synthesis of sulphur containing aminoacid leads to deficiency of cysteine and methionine.
  • Hairs are rough and fragile resulting in Tiger tail appearance.
  • Clinically patient presents with diffuse sparseness and broken hair all over the scalp since childhood.

questions.text: A 35 year old female presented with a history of intense hair fall for the past 4 months. She had COVID 8 months ago. What could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Telogen effluvium occurs after significant systemic stress (eg. Malaria, dengue, typhoid, major illness or surgery)

It lead to premature follicular transition from anagen to telogen lead to diffuse hair fall.

Telogen hair start to shed after 3 months leading to diffuse hair fall after 3-4 months.

COVID induced telogen effluvium

  • Cytokine storm IL-6, IL-4
  • Induction of catagen
  • keratinocyte apoptosis

Option A: Female pattern hair loss is progressive gradual hair loss with widening of the central part.

Option C: Anagen effluvium

  • Anagen effluvium results from disturbance in the anagen phase of hair.
  • Cancer chemotherapy, radiation, toxins lead to sudden hair loss within 15 days.
  • Anagen hair has a pigmented hair bulb.
  • Hair regrows after the etiological factor is removed.

Option D: Trichotillomania patient present with patchy hair loss over accessible areas

  • Trichotillomania (TTM) also known as hair-pulling disorder,
  • Classical tonsular appearance (Friar tuck appearance)
  • Trichoscopy of trichotillomania is characterized by presence of hairs broken at different length, black dots, trichoptilosis, coiled hairs, flame hairs, V-sign and tulip hairs.

Key takeaway:

  • Telogen effluvium occurs after significant systemic stress (eg. Malaria, dengue,typhoid, major illness or surgery)
  • Telogen hair start to shed after 3 months leading to diffuse hair fall after 3-4 months.

questions.text: A Child with alopecia presented with itching over the site of hair loss. Sibling also has a similar lesion. Scraping from the patch shows the following finding. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
A patchy alopecia in a child could have differential diagnosis.

  • Alopecia areata (Asymptomatic, smooth bald patch, Non infectious)
  • Trichotillomania (Hair loss in accessible area, Habit of hair pulling, Asymptomatic)
  • Tinea capitis (Associated with itching, Family history could be positive due to infective etiology)

It is a dermatophyte infection of hair. It occurs predominantly in prepubertal

The clinical features may be broadly categorized into non-inflammatory and inflammatory variants.

Given case is non inflammatory variant of T. Capitis

G- Grey patch

M- Microsporum

C- ECtothrix

B- Black dot

N- ENdothrix

T- Trichophyton

Grey patch:

Black dot:

Key Takeaway:

Non inflammatory variant of T. Capitis:

G- Grey patch

M- Microsporum

C- ECtothrix

B- Black dot

N- ENdothrix

T- Trichophyton

questions.text: The image is showing patchy hair loss in a 16 year old female. What is the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Trichotillomania

  • Trichotillomania (TTM) also known as hair-pulling disorder,
  • Trichotillomania is part of OCD and is thought to be largely related to anxiety disorders.
  • More common in females of adolescent age group.

Classical tonsular appearance (Friar tuck appearance)

  • Sometimes traumatic pulling of hair can lead to bleeding.
  • Trichoscopy of trichotillomania is characterized by presence of hairs broken at different length, black dots, trichoptilosis, coiled hairs, flame hairs, V-sign and tulip hairs.

Option B: Alopecia areata

  • Autoimmune lymphocytic damage pigmented hair leading to hair loss.
  • Patient presents with smooth bald patch with sparing of greyhair.
  • On dermoscopy, there is classical exclamation hair.
  • In histopathology, lymphocytic infiltration around hair follicle (Swarm of bees appearance) is seen

There are three main types of alopecia areata:

Option C: Tinea capitis

It is dermatophyte infection of hair. It occurs predominantly in prepubertal children.

The clinical features may be broadly categorised into non-inflammatory and inflammatory variants.

Option D: FPHL

Female pattern hair loss usually presents as thinning rather than patchy loss and typically occurs in older individuals. Widening of the central part is seen.

Key takeaway:

  • Trichotillomania (TTM) also known as hair-pulling disorder,
  • Trichotillomania is part of OCD and is thought to be largely related to anxiety disorders. More common in females of adolescent age group.
  • Classical tonsular appearance (Friar tuck appearance)
  • Trichoscopy of trichotillomania is characterized by the presence of hairs broken at different lengths, black dots, trichoptilosis, coiled hairs, flame hairs, V-sign and tulip hairs.

questions.text: A women presenting with acne which is resistant to multiple cycles of antibiotics and non responsive to oral. What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
This patient is having mandibular acne, which is seen in hormonal imbalance. Hormonal acne is not responsive to oral antibiotics. Thus, patients should be assessed for hyperandrogenism.

Hyperandrogenism is a condition characterized by excessive production of male sex hormones (androgens) in women. The most common cause is polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

Syndromes Associated with Hyperandrogenism:

  1. SAHA syndrome: This acronym stands for:
    • Seborrhea: Excessive oil production in the skin.
    • Acne: Inflammatory skin condition with pimples and blackheads.
    • Hirsutism: Excessive hair growth in male-pattern areas.
    • Alopecia: Hair loss.
  2. HAIRAN syndrome: This acronym stands for:
    • Hyperandrogenism: Excessive male hormone production.
    • Acanthosis nigricans: Darkening and thickening of the skin in folds and creases.
    • Insulin Resistance: Decreased sensitivity to insulin, leading to difficulty controlling blood sugar levels.

Option B, C & D: Assess for antibiotic resistance,Dietary modification & Drug induced acne all are possible management options however This patient is having mandibular acne, which is seen in hormonal imbalance. Hormonal acne is not responsive to oral antibiotics. Thus, patients should be assessed for hyperandrogenism.

Key takeaway:

Hormonal Acne:

  • Antibiotic resistant acne
  • Female with mandibular acne
  • Due to hyperandrogenism
  • Management: Cyproterone acetate + Ethinyl estradiol

questions.text: Which drug used for acne management can leads to pigmentation?
questions.solution:
Oral Minocycline is used for acne vulgaris. It is indicated for severe acne, or moderate acne not responding to topical therapy.

Side effects of minocycline:

Drug hypersensitivity syndrome, Hyperpigmentation of skin, melanonychia.

Option A- Doxycycline

  • Photosensitivity

Option B- Isotretinoin

  • Teratogenic drug
  • Cheilitis

Option C- Cyproterone acetate ethinyl estradiol

  • Usually safe

Key takeaway:

Minocycline used for acne management leads to pigmentation of skin.

questions.text: A 24 year old 5 months amenorrheic female presented with erythematous papules over face. What would be safe in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Acne Medications During Pregnancy

Vitamin A derivatives are indeed teratogenic, meaning they can cause birth defects. Therefore, tretinoin, adapalene, and tazarotene should be avoided during pregnancy.

Safe Acne Medications During Pregnancy

Here are some acne medications that are generally considered safe for use during pregnancy:

  • Topical azelaic acid: This medication has been shown to be safe for use during pregnancy.
  • Topical benzoyl peroxide: This over-the-counter medication is often used safely during pregnancy.
  • Oral and topical erythromycin: Erythromycin is generally considered safe for use during pregnancy.

Option A, B & D: Vitamin A derivatives are teratogenic. Thus, Tretinoin, Adapalene and Tazarotene are not safe in pregnancy.

Key takeaway:

Acne in pregnancy

  • Management - Topical azelaic acid, Topical benzoyl peroxide, Oral and topical erythromycin
  • Avoid VIt A derivatives - teratogenic

questions.text: What will be the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows grade 4 acne

Isotretinoin is the most efficacious treatment for severe acne(grade 4).

Isotretinoin is the only therapy that impacts on all of the major aetiological factors implicated in acne.

It results in a significant reduction in sebum production, influences comedogenesis, lowers surface and ductal P. acnes and has anti-inflammatory properties. A dose of 0.5-1.0 mg/kg/day dramatically reduces acne.

Key Takeaway:

Acne grade 4-Nodulocystic acne is treated with Oral isotretinoin. It causes  side effects like Chelitis, raised LFT and Teratogenicity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with a noticeably enlarged, red, and bulbous nose. The patient has a long-standing history of facial redness and acne-like eruptions. On examination, the nasal skin shows thickening and a prominent, irregular appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Rhinophyma is a subtype of rosacea characterized by thickening of the nasal skin, leading to a bulbous and irregular appearance. It typically occurs in patients with a long history of rosacea, particularly those with significant facial redness and acne-like eruptions.

Option A: Acne vulgaris typically affects adolescents and young adults and presents with comedones, papules, and pustules, rather than the thickened, bulbous nasal appearance seen in rhinophyma.

Option C & D: Basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma are types of skin cancer that might present with nodules or irregular lesions, but they do not typically cause the characteristic thickening and bulbous appearance associated with rhinophyma.

Key takeaway:

Rhinophyma:

Long term Rosacea - Erythema, papular eruption

Lead to thickening of nose - Bulbous, irregular nose

questions.text: A 23 year old male presented with white coloured tine skin lesion over lips. The lesions are asymptomatic. What is the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Fordyce spots are ectopic sebaceous glands. Normal sebaceous glands open in the hair follicle. Fordyce spot open directly into skin or mucosa.

Common sites are upper lip, buccal mucosa, penile shaft.

Fordyce spot over the penile shaft are called Tyson glands.

They are asymptomatic and no treatment is required.

Option A- Leukoplakia: Typically presents as white patches in the oral cavity that may be a sign of potential precancerous changes.

Option B- Herpes labialis: Usually presents with painful, blistering lesions and is caused by the herpes simplex virus.

Option C- Oral lichen planus: Presents with white, lacy lesions that can be symptomatic and may involve other areas of the oral cavity.

Given the presentation of asymptomatic white lesions over the lips, D- Fordyce spots is indeed the most appropriate diagnosis.

Key takeaway:

  • Fordyce spot- Ectopic sebaceous gland
  • Common sites are upper lip, buccal mucosa, penile shaft.
  • Asymptomatic

questions.text: A 35 year old male presented with a chronic history of recurrent, painful nodules which rupture to form sinus tract in axilla and groin. Which structure is involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
• Hidradenitis suppurativa is a disease of apocrine glands.
  • It is also known as "inverse acne".
  • Occurs in apocrine area like axilla, inguinal, anogenital region.
  • Patient presents with recurrent nodule, abscess, sinuses and scarring.
  • Secondary bacterial infection occurs.
  • Management by antibiotics, oral retinoids, and for severe and recalcitrant disease Infliximab is helpful.

B- Eccrine Sweat Glands

  • Function: Thermoregulation
  • Location: They are distributed widely across the body, especially on the palms, soles, and forehead.
  • Associated Conditions: hyperhidrosis (excessive sweating) or miliaria (heat rash).

C- Sebaceous Glands

  • Function: secrete sebum
  • Location: associated with hair follicles and are found throughout the skin, except on the palms and soles.
  • Associated Conditions: acne,

D- Hair

  • Location: Hair follicles are found throughout the body.
  • Associated Conditions: folliculitis or pilonidal disease,

Key takeaway:

  • Hidradenitis suppurativa is a disease of apocrine glands.
  • It is also known as "inverse acne".
  • Occurs in apocrine area like axilla, inguinal, anogenital region.
  • Patient presents with recurrent nodule, abscess, sinuses and scarring.

questions.text: A female patient presented with intensely itchy papules in the axilla as shown in the image. What would be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fox-Fordyce disease (FFD), an eponym for apocrine miliaria, is a rare chronic inflammatory skin disorder of the apocrine glands characterized by a pruritic papular eruption in the apocrine gland-rich parts of the body, including the axillae, areolae, anogenital region, among others.

Miliaria is the retention of sweat due to obstruction of eccrine ducts. It is common in hot and humid climates.

Types of miliaria depending upon level of obstruction:

Miliaria crystallina - Clear vesicles, Obstruction at level of stratum corneum(Option C)

Miliaria rubra - Most common type, Red itchy papules with pricking sensation, Obstruction at the level of Lower epidermis and upper dermis. (Option B)

Miliaria profunda - Large inflamed papules, obstruction at deep dermis.

Option D: Fordyce spots are ectopic sebaceous glands.

Normal sebaceous glands open in the hair follicle. Fordyce spot open directly into skin or mucosa. Common sites are upper lip, buccal mucosa, penile shaft.

Key takeaway:

  • Fox-Fordyce disease (FFD), an eponym for apocrine miliaria,
  • characterized by a pruritic papular eruption in the apocrine gland-rich parts of the body, including the axillae, areolae, anogenital region, among others.

questions.text: A male child with mild painful swelling in the scalp for 3 months is associated with hair loss. The patient has a dog pet at home. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Kerion

  • Kerion is a severe inflammatory reaction to a fungal infection of the scalp, typically caused by dermatophytes like Trichophyton
  • It presents as a painful, swollen, and often exudative mass on the scalp, leading to hair loss.
  • The association with a pet dog is relevant, as dogs can be carriers of dermatophytes that cause tinea capitis.
  • The chronic, painful nature of the swelling and hair loss is characteristic of kerion.

Tinea capitis is a dermatophyte infection of hair. It occurs predominantly in prepubertal children.

Option A - Folliculitis

Folliculitis is an infection of the hair follicles that presents as small red or pus-filled swelling around the hair follicles. It is typically less severe than kerion and does not usually cause significant hair loss or swelling. The presentation in this case is more severe than typical folliculitis.

Option B - Abscess

An abscess is a localized collection of pus that can occur anywhere in the body, including the scalp. It can cause pain and swelling, but it is usually more acute and may be accompanied by systemic symptoms. Abscesses are less commonly associated with hair loss

Option D - Sebaceous cyst

A sebaceous cyst is a non-infectious, benign growth that occurs when sebaceous glands become blocked. It typically presents as a slow-growing, non-painful lump on the scalp.

Key takeaway:

  • Kerion is a severe inflammatory reaction to a fungal infection of the scalp, typically caused by dermatophytes like Trichophyton
  • It presents as a painful, swollen, and often exudative mass on the scalp, leading to hair loss.
  • The association with a pet dog is relevant, as dogs can be carriers of dermatophytes that cause tinea capitis.
  • The chronic, painful nature of the swelling and hair loss is characteristic of kerion.

questions.text: A 6 months old male patient presented with itching and skin lesions since 2 days. Picture of the baby is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Retention of sweat due to obstruction of eccrine ducts. It is common in hot and humid climates.

Types of miliaria depending upon level of obstruction:

  • Miliaria crystallina - Clear vesicles, Obstruction at level of stratum corneum__(Option B)
  • Miliaria rubra - Most common type, Red itchy papules with pricking sensation, Obstruction at the level of Lower epidermis and upper dermis.___(Option A)
  • Miliaria profunda - Large inflamed papules, obstruction at deep dermis.__(Option C)
  • Miliaria pustulosa - Pustules present in malaria rubra__ (Option D)

Key takeaway:

Miliaria: Retention of sweat due to obstruction of eccrine ducts

3 types:

  • Miliaria crystallina
  • Miliaria rubra
  • Miliaria profunda
